channel.title: The Complete List of Networking Terms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in The Complete List of Networking Terms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is Cloud Security Control?
item.description: Cloud security controls refer to the measures that organizations put in place to ensure the security and integrity of their data and systems when using cloud computing services.

item.title: What is a Zone File?
item.description: A zone file is a configuration file that is used to define the DNS (Domain Name System) information for a particular domain.

item.title: What is a Permalink?
item.description: A permalink, short for “permanent link,” is a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that is intended to remain unchanged for the lifetime of the content to which it refers.

item.title: What is Grid Computing?
item.description: Grid computing is a distributed computing paradigm that involves the use of a large number of computers to solve complex problems or perform large-scale data processing tasks.

item.title: What is Email?
item.description: Email, or electronic mail, is a method of exchanging digital messages between computers.

item.title: What is a DNS (Domain Name System)?
item.description: A Domain Name System (DNS) is a decentralized system that translates human-readable domain names, such as example.

item.title: What is a Datagram?
item.description: A “datagram” is a self-contained, independent entity of data carrying sufficient information to be routed from the source to the destination computer without reliance on earlier exchanges between the source and destination computers and the transporting network.

item.title: What is 5G?
item.description: 5G is the fifth generation of mobile network technology that is designed to provide faster and more reliable internet connectivity to devices such as smartphones, tablets, and laptops.

item.title: What is 4G?
item.description: 4G is a mobile telecommunications technology that lets smartphones and tablets connect to the internet at high speeds.

item.title: What is the 404 Error (Not Found)?
item.description: The 404 error is an HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) status code that indicates that the server was unable to find the requested resource.

item.title: What is the 403 Error (Forbidden)?
item.description: A 403 error is an HTTP status code that indicates that a client is forbidden from accessing a requested resource.

item.title: What is 3G?
item.description: 3G, or third generation, is a generation of wireless mobile telecommunications technology.

item.title: What is a TCP Wrapper?
item.description: A “wrapper” is a layer of software that provides an additional layer of abstraction between two different systems or protocols.

item.title: What is NBA (Network Behavior Analysis)?
item.description: Network behavior analysis is a cybersecurity technique that involves the continuous monitoring and analysis of network traffic and activity to identify unusual or malicious behavior.

item.title: What is CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
item.description: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a globally distributed network of servers that work together to deliver content to users as efficiently as possible.

item.title: What is Star Topology?
item.description: Star topology is a type of network architecture in which each device on the network is connected to a central hub or switch.

item.title: What is UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply)?
item.description: An uninterruptible power supply (UPS) is a device that provides backup power to a computer, server, or other electronic equipment in the event of an interruption or fluctuation in the main power supply.

item.title: What is NFC (Near Field Communication)?
item.description: Near Field Communication (NFC) is a short-range wireless technology that allows for the exchange of data or power between devices.

item.title: What is User Identification?
item.description: User identification is the process of identifying and authenticating a user’s identity in order to grant them access to a system or service.

item.title: What is IT Healthcare?
item.description: Information technology (IT) in healthcare refers to the use of computers, software, and other digital tools to manage and process information in the healthcare industry.

item.title: What is Network Topology?
item.description: Network topology refers to the layout or structure of a network.

item.title: What is Wireless Charging?
item.description: Wireless charging is a technology that allows devices to be charged without the need for a physical connection to a charger or power outlet.

item.title: What is DAC (Discretionary Access Control)?
item.description: Discretionary Access Control (DAC) is a type of access control that is based on the idea that an individual user or process has the discretion to grant or revoke access to resources that they own or control.

item.title: What is ICT (Information and Communications Technology)?
item.description: Information and communications technology, or ICT, refers to the various technologies and tools used to facilitate the exchange of information and communication.

item.title: What is Parity Check?
item.description: “Parity check” is a method of checking the accuracy of data transmission or storage.

item.title: What is a Home Page?
item.description: A home page is the main or front page of a website.

item.title: What is the Web?
item.description: The World Wide Web, commonly referred to as the “Web,” is a vast network of interconnected documents and other resources linked by hyperlinks and URLs.

item.title: What is Latency?
item.description: Latency is the time it takes for a signal or a request to be transmitted and received by a system.

item.title: What is Edge Computing?
item.description: Edge computing is a distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the edge of the network, where data is generated and consumed.

item.title: What is Social Engineering?
item.description: Social engineering is a term used to describe the psychological manipulation of individuals into performing actions or divulging sensitive information.

item.title: What is a Wireless Adapter?
item.description: A wireless adapter is a device that connects to a computer or other device and allows it to communicate over a wireless network.

item.title: What is a Network Adapter?
item.description: A network adapter, also known as a network interface card (NIC), is a hardware component that allows a computer to connect to a network.

item.title: What is an Access Point (AP)?
item.description: An access point (AP) is a device that allows wireless devices to connect to a network using Wi-Fi or a similar wireless technology.
